Ghostwriter looked really great, but in the fifteen minutes or so since I've installed it it's already crashed twice. The first time I was just setting up my preferences, so I thought maybe it needed to adjust to my settings. I restarted my computer and tried again. This time I was happily writing away when it crashed again. It completely lost all my work and seems to have no record that I'd even written anything at all. If this app worked it looks like it would be great. I hope this problem gets fixed quickly because I was really looking forward to using it.

...seems to be the philosophy behind this joke of a markdown editor. 

Cannot open more than one file at a time, so no way to compare two files side by side or reference one while working on another. Opening an existing file or creating a new one automatically closes the one currenly open without any prompt or notice and automatically saves any changes you made, whether you wanted to or not. Say goodbye to your undo history every time you dare to commit the sin of changing context to another document. And look forward to your ~/Documents directory being polluted with countless unwelcome untitled*.md files.

The "Hemmingway mode" which prevents using backspace to simulate the experience of using an antiquated typewritter should tell you everything you need to know about the hipster design philosophy behind this gimmicky piece of novelty software. It would be right at home in the "it's not a bug, it's a feature" landscape of the ios app store, but KDE frankly deserves a better markdown editor.

A perfect distraction free editor. Install pandoc and latex with this and you just have an amazing editor for your papers, novels, docs, etc... 

Just one thing missing: more flexibility on the "output". It would be great to be able to choose from the "export" window a (e.g.) latex template for the document. At the moment you can have a YaML header, but it is not perfect.
